response: Yes, absolutely ban them. My son started gambling after seeing these ads during football matches. It's predatory marketing targeting vulnerable people when they're relaxed and enjoying sports.
A complete ban would be excessive. These companies fund sports through sponsorships. Without their money, ticket prices would skyrocket and grassroots sports would suffer.
The constant gambling ads are ruining sports for families. Can't watch a match with kids without explaining betting odds. Ban them completely.
I don't see the problem. Adults can make their own choices. If someone wants to bet, they'll find a way regardless of TV ads.
As a recovering gambling addict, these ads are torture. Watching sports was my escape, now it's a minefield of triggers. Please ban them.
The revenue from gambling companies keeps subscription costs down. Without it, only wealthy people could afford to watch sports.
It's not just about banning ads - we need better education about gambling risks in schools and communities.
My local football club survives on gambling sponsorship. A ban would literally kill grassroots sports in deprived areas.
The normalisation of gambling through sports is dangerous. Young people think betting is just part of being a sports fan now.
Watershed restrictions would be better than an outright ban. No gambling ads before 9pm protects children while preserving revenue.
These ads prey on people's emotions during exciting moments. It's manipulative and should be illegal.
Lost my house because of gambling addiction that started with 'harmless' football bets. Ban all gambling ads immediately.
Personal responsibility matters. Banning ads won't stop problem gambling, just hurt legitimate businesses.
The integration of betting into sports commentary is insidious. Presenters discussing odds normalizes gambling for viewers.
A ban would reduce sports coverage. Broadcasters rely on ad revenue to afford broadcasting rights.
My teenage son knows more about accumulator bets than his times tables. This has to stop.
Gambling ads fund women's sports that otherwise get no coverage. A ban would disproportionately harm female athletes.
Every ad break during the match is wall-to-wall betting. It's excessive and needs strict limits at minimum.
Why single out gambling? Alcohol ads during sports are just as harmful but nobody talks about banning those.
The free bet offers are the worst - they hook you in with 'free' money then you're trapped.
Sports and gambling have always gone together. It's part of the culture and tradition.
Watching sports with my dad used to be about the game. Now half the conversation is about bets and odds.
Other countries manage fine without gambling ads during sports. The UK can too.
The ads themselves aren't the problem - it's the lack of support for problem gamblers that needs addressing.
I work in broadcasting. Without gambling ad revenue, we'd lose most live sports coverage.
These companies specifically target matches with younger audiences. It's calculated and predatory.
Maybe limit frequency rather than ban? One gambling ad per break maximum.
My gambling started with a 'risk-free' bet advertised during the World Cup. Nearly destroyed my family.
If we ban gambling ads, we should ban all 'vice' advertising - alcohol, junk food, etc. Where does it end?
The subliminal messaging in these ads is sophisticated. They use psychological tricks to create addiction.
Small bookmakers employ thousands. A ban would devastate communities already struggling economically.
Children absorb these messages. My 8-year-old asked what odds meant during a match. That's not right.
Voluntary restrictions haven't worked. The industry can't self-regulate. We need a legal ban.
The hypocrisy is staggering - government takes tax from gambling then complains about social costs.
Sports survived fine before gambling sponsorship. They'll adapt and find other revenue sources.
Problem gambling costs the NHS millions. Factor that in when considering the 'benefits' of ad revenue.
Ray Winstone telling me to bet responsibly while encouraging me to bet is paradoxical.
Regional sports coverage would disappear without gambling sponsorship. It's the only thing keeping it viable.
The ads make gambling seem glamorous and sophisticated. Reality is very different for addicts.
Education and treatment programs should be funded by gambling companies, not just token gestures.
I enjoy a flutter occasionally. Don't punish responsible gamblers because some can't control themselves.
The speed of in-play betting advertised during matches is particularly dangerous. No time to think.
My son's football team is sponsored by a betting company. Mixed messages everywhere.
Compromise: allow brand advertising but ban specific odds and offers during broadcasts.
The gambling industry employs hundreds of thousands. Consider the economic impact of a ban.
These ads target vulnerable men specifically. It's gendered predatory marketing.
Stadium naming rights, shirt sponsorship, TV ads - gambling has infected every aspect of sport.
We banned tobacco advertising and sports survived. Same thing can happen with gambling.
The constant odds updates during commentary are worse than the ads. Ban that too.
Gambling addiction destroyed my marriage. These ads are like showing drugs to recovering addicts.
Free market principles apply. If people don't like the ads, they can choose not to watch.
Young men are particularly vulnerable. Suicide rates linked to gambling debt are shocking.
A ban is too extreme. Better age verification and spending limits would be more effective.
The ads are so frequent now, they've lost impact anyway. People just tune them out.
My elderly father was scammed by a betting site advertised during snooker. Vulnerable people need protection.
Sports broadcasters are complicit. They've sold their souls for gambling money.
Restricting ads won't stop online gambling. People will just see ads elsewhere on the internet.
The 'when the fun stops, stop' tagline is insulting. Addiction doesn't work that way.
Lower league clubs would fold without betting sponsorship. It's their financial lifeline.
The government makes too much tax revenue from gambling to ever ban ads properly.
Celebrity endorsements make it worse. Role models shouldn't promote gambling to fans.
Other forms of advertising like social media are more concerning than TV ads.
My kids can recite betting company jingles but not their times tables. Society's priorities are wrong.
The ads are annoying but harmless. People gambled long before TV advertising existed.
Match-fixing scandals increase when gambling is normalized. It corrupts sport itself.
I've worked in addiction services. Gambling causes more hidden harm than drugs or alcohol.
The ads fund free-to-air sport. Without them, everything moves to expensive subscriptions.
Gambling companies exploit tribal loyalty. Fans bet on their team even when odds are terrible.
Technology exists to block ads for individual households. Let people choose for themselves.
The charity shields betting companies use are transparent attempts to avoid regulation.
Provincial sports journalism would die without gambling company advertising revenue.
My nephew thinks betting is a viable career because of these ads. It's warping young minds.
The solution is simple: treat gambling ads like cigarette ads. Complete ban.
Responsible gambling messages are like 'drink responsibly' - token gestures that mean nothing.
The odds shown during live sports are the worst. It's like product placement on steroids.
Scotland's restrictions show it can be done without killing sports coverage.
The gambling lobby is too powerful. Politicians won't bite the hand that feeds them.
VIP programs advertised during sports are particularly predatory, targeting big losers.
If adults want to gamble, that's their choice. Stop the nanny state interfering.
The mental health crisis among young men is directly linked to gambling promotion in sports.
Shirt sponsorship is worse than TV ads. Kids wear their heroes' jerseys covered in betting logos.
The economic argument is overstated. Sports thrived before gambling money arrived.
Addiction treatment should be funded by a levy on gambling companies who advertise.
The ads wouldn't be so bad if they showed the reality of problem gambling too.
Freedom of commercial speech matters. Banning legal business from advertising sets bad precedent.

The issue isn't ads but ease of access. Phone betting is the real problem.
Sports pundits giving betting tips alongside match analysis normalizes gambling.
If we're banning harmful ads, start with payday loans and junk food, not gambling.
The false promise of easy money in these ads targets desperate people in tough times.
Minor sports only get TV coverage because of gambling company sponsorship deals.
Three friends lost everything to gambling that started with sports bets. Ban the ads now.
The integration is so deep now, you can't separate modern sport from gambling.
Let the market decide. If people object to gambling ads, viewing figures will drop.
The safeguarding of children should override any economic arguments about revenue.
Gambling companies already face heavy regulation. Adding more will just drive them offshore.
The ads are a symptom, not the cause. Focus on treating addiction, not banning commercials.
Women's sports would lose millions in sponsorship. This ban would hurt gender equality.
My gambling addiction started with a free bet offered during the football. Gateway drug.
Sports needs to find ethical sponsors. Short-term pain for long-term gain.
